abstract: The Moment talked to Meir Kordevani about his elegant pictures-only publication.
snippet: The Moment talked to Meir Kordevani about his elegant pictures-only publication.
lead_paragraph: I recently played an on-line game with the artist Lucas Samaras in which the objective is to place a random assortment of finely nuanced colors in order as speedily as possible. I lost, and it wasn't simply because I was up against art's slyest color master since Matisse. A brain as visually acute is something of a four-leaf clover: it's real but you can be easily mistaken when you think you've found one. Caught, as we are today, in an unprecedented visual monsoon there is good reason to believe that this is changing. A younger generation's visual palette (if not literacy) may grossly outpace anything Marshall McLuhan or we could ever have imagined.
